editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The widow a comedy. As it was acted at the private house in Blackfriars, with great applause, by his late majesty's servants.

Written by
Ben: Johnson. gent.
John Fletcher. gent.
Tho. Middleton. gent.
London, printed for Humphrey Moseley and are to be sold at his shop, at the sign of the prince's arms in st. Paul's churchyard. 1652.

div.head: To the reader.
div.p: Considering how the curious pay some part of their esteem to excellent persons in the careful preservation but of their defaced statues, instead of decayed medals of the Romans greatness, I believed it of more value to present you this lively piece, drawn by the art of Johnson, Fletcher, and Middleton, which is thought to have a near resemblance to the portraiture we have in Terence of those worthy minds, where the great Scipio and Laelius strove to twist the poet's ivy with the victor's bays. As the one was deserved by their work in subduing their countries enemies, so the other, by their recreation and delight which was to banish that folly and sadness, that were worse than Hannibal, or all the monsters and venom of Africa. Since our own countrymen are not in any thing inferior, it were to be wished, they had but so much encouragement, that the past licence and abuses charged on the stage, might not ever be thought too unpardonable to pass in oblivion, and so good laws and instructions for manners uncapable of being regulated, which if but according to this pattern, certainly none need think himself the less a good christian for owning the same desire as

list.item: 2 old men suitors to the widow.
Ricardo, a decayed young gent. and suitor to the widow.
Martia, daughter to one of the old suitors and supposed a man.

div.head: Actus 1. Scoena 1.
div.stage: Enter signior Martino (An old justice's clerk) and Francisco.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Signior Francisco? you're the luckiest gentleman to meet
Or see first in a morning: I never saw you yet
But I was sure of money within less than half an hour.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I bring you the same luck still.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What you do not?
I hope sir you are not come for another warrant?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes faith, for another warrant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Why there's my dream come out then. I never dreamed of a buttock but I was sure to have money for a warrant. It is the luckiest part of all the body to me: let every man speak as he finds. Now your usurer is of opinion, that to dream of the devil is your wealthier dream; and I think if a man dream of that part that brings many to the devil, 'tis as good; and has all one smatch indeed; for if one be the flesh, th'others the
broth: so 'tis in all his members and we mark it; if gluttony be the meat, lechery is the porridge, they're both boiled together, and we clerks will have our modicum too, though it conclude in the two penny chop: why sir, signior Francisco.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Twas her voice sure,
Or my soul takes delight to think it was,
And makes a sound like hers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It is the prettiest contrived building, this:
What poesy's that I prithee?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Which sir, that
Under the great brass squirt?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I that sir, that

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: From fire, from water, and all things amiss,
Deliver the house of an honest justice?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: There's like to be a good house kept then, when fire and water's forbidden to come into the kitchen. Not yet a sight of her? this hour's unfortunate. And what's that yonder prithee? O loves famine, there's no affliction like thee. Ay, I hear you sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You're quicker eared than I then: you hear me
Before I heard myself.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A gift in friendship
Some call it an instinct.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It may be
Th' other's the sweeter phrase though; look you sir,
Mine own wit this, and 'tis as true as turtle;
A goose-quill and a clerk, a constable and a lantern,
Brings many a bawd from coach to cart, and many a thief to one turn.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That one turn helped you well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
'Thas helped me to money indeed for many a warrant. I am 40. dollars the better for that one-turn; and 'twould come off quicker 'twere ne'er a whit the worse for me. But indeed when thieves are taken, and break away twice or thrice one after another, there's my gains; then goes out more warrants to fetch 'em again: one fine nimble villain, may be worth a man ten dollars in and out a that fashion; I love such a one with my heart, ay, and
will help him to scape to, and I can; hear you me that: I'll have him in at all times at a month's warning: nay, say I let him run like a summer nag all the vacation: see you these blanks, I'll send him but one of these bridles, and bring him in at Michaelmas with a vengeance: nothing kills my heart, but when one of 'em dies sir; then there's no hope of more money: I had rather lose at all times two of my best kindred, than an excellent thief: for he's a gentleman I'm more beholding to.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You betray your mystery too much sir. Yet no comfort?
'Tis but her sight that I waste precious time for,
For more I cannot hope for, she's so strict,
Yet that I cannot have.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'm ready now signior.

div.p: Here are blank warrants of all dispositions, give me but the name and nature of your malefactor, and I'll bestow him according to his merits.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This only is th' excuse that bears me out,
And keeps off impudence and suspicion
From my too frequent coming: what name now
Shall I think on, and not to wrong the house?
This coxcomb will be prating. — one Astilio,
His offence wilful murder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Wilful murder? o I love a life to have such a fellow come under my fingers; like a beggar that's long a taking leave of a fat louse, I'm loath to part with him, I must look upon him over and over first; are you wilful? i'faith, I'll be as wilful as you then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mistress?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Make haste, your master's going.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'm but about a wilful murder forsooth, I'll dispatch that presently.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Good morrow sir: o that I durst say more.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis gone again, since; such are all life's pleasures,
No sooner known, but lost; he that enjoys 'em
The length of life, has but a longer dream,
He wakes to this i'th end, and sees all nothing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He cannot see me now; I'll mark him better
Before I be too rash: sweetly composed he is;
Now as he stands, he's worth a woman's love,
that loves only for shape, as most on's do:
But I must have him wise, as well as proper,
He comes not in my books else, and indeed
I have thought upon a course to try his wit: Violetta.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yonder's the gentleman again.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O sweet mistress
Pray give me leave to see him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay take heed,
Open not the window and you love me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: No, I've the view of whole body here, mistress,
At this poor little slit, o enough, enough,
In troth 'tis a fine outside.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I see that.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Has curled his hair most judiciously well.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I there's thy love, now, it begins in barbarism: she buys a goose with feathers, that loves a gentleman for's hair; she may be cozened to her face wench. Away: he takes his leave. Reach me that letter hither, quick ▪ quick wench.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay look upon't, and spare not: every one cannot get that kind of warrant from me signior. Do you see this prick i'th bottom, it betokens power and speed, it is a privy mark, that runs betwixt the constables and my Mr. those that cannot read, when they see this, know 'tis for lechery or murder, and this being away, the warrant comes gelded, and insufficient.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I thank you sir,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Look you; all these are nihils,
They want the punction.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, I see they do sir,
There's for thy pains, mine must go unrewarded.
The better love, the worse by fate regarded.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, go thy ways, for the sweetest customer that ever penman was blessed withal: now will he come for another tomorrow again; if he hold on this course, he will leave never a knave i'th town within this twelvemonth : no matter, I shall be rich enough by that time.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Say you forsooth.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What paper's that the gentleman let fall there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l:
Paper? 'tis the warrant I hope, if it be I'll hide it, and
make him pay for't again. No pox: 'tis not so happy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What is't sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing but a letter forsooth.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is that nothing?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nothing, in respect of a warrant mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A letter? why 'thas been many a man's undoing sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So has a warrant, and you go to that mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil,
sp.l: Read but the superscription; and away with't:
Alas it may concern the gentleman nearly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why mistress, this letter is at home already.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: At home, how mean your sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You shall hear mistress. To the deservingest of all her sex, and most worthy of his best respect and love, Mrs. Philippa Brandino.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How sir, to me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To you mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Run, as thou lovest my honour, and thy life,
Call him again, I'll not endure this injury:
But stay, stay now I think on't, 'tis my credit,
I'll have your master's counsel: ah base fellow
To leave his loose lines thus; 'tis even as much
As a poor honest gentlewoman's undoing,
Had I not a grave wiseman to my husband:
And thou a vigilant varlet to admit
Thou carest not whom

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas 'tis my office mistress.
You know you have a kirtle every year,
And 'tis within two months of the time now,
sp.p: The velvets coming over: pray be milder; a man that has a place must take money of anybody : please you to throw me down but half a dollar, and I'll make you a warrant for him now, that's all I care for him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, look you be clear now from this foul conspiracy
Against mine honour; or your master's love to you
That makes you stout, shall not maintain you here;
It shall not: trust to 't. —Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is strange to me now:
Dare she do this, and but eight weeks to new-year's tide?
A man that had his blood as hot as hers now, would fit her with
French velvet: I'll go near it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If this be a wrong to modest reputation
Be you the censurer sir, that are the master
Both of your fame and mine.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Signior Francisco?
I'll make him fly the land.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That will be hard sir;
I think he be not so well feathered master,
Has spent the best part of his patrimony.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hark of his bold confederate.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: There thour't bitter;
And I must chide thee now.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What should I think sir?
He comes to your man for warrants.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: There it goes then;
Come hither knave: comes he to you for warrants?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, what of that sir?
You know I give no warrants to make cuckolds,
That comes by fortune, and by nature sir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: True, that comes by fortune, and by nature; wife
Why dost thou wrong this man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He needs no warrant master, that goes about such business, a cuckold-maker carries always his warrant about him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: La: has he answered well now? to the full?
What cause hast thou to abuse him?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hear me out I pray:
Through his admittance, has had opportunity
To come into the house, and court me bodily.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Sirrah, you're foul again methinks .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who I sir?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: You gave this man admittance into th' th'house.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's true sir, you never gave me any order yet
To write my warrants ith' street.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why sure thou takest delight to wrong this fellow, wife:
Ha, cause I love him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray see the fruits: see what has left behind here:
Be angry where you should be: there's few wives
Would do as I do

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Nay I'll say that for thee
I ne'er found thee but honest.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She's a beast
that ever was found otherways.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Read Martino,
Mine eyes are sore already, and such business
Would put 'em out quite

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fair, dear and incomparable mistress, —

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Oh! every letter draws a tooth methinks .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And it leads mine to watering.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Here's no villainy?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My love being so violent, and the opportunity so precious in your husband's absence tonight , who as I understand takes a journey this morning.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: O plot of villainy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Am I honest think you sir?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Exactly honest, perfectly improved: on, on Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I will make bold dear mistress, though your chastity has given me many a repulse, to wait the sweet blessings of this long desired opportunity, at the back gate, between nine and ten this night.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I feel this Inns-a-court man in my temples.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where if your affection be pleased to receive me, you receive the faithfullest that ever vowed service to woman — Francisco.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I will make Francisco smart for't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Show him the letter, let him know, you know him;
That will torment him: all your other courses
Are nothing sir to that: that breaks his heart.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: The strings shall not hold long then: come Martino.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now if Francisco have any wit at all,
He comes at night; if not, he never shall.

div.head: Scoena. 2.
div.stage: Enter Francisco and Ricardo and Attilio.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Nay mark, mark it Francisco: it was the naturalest courtesy that ever was ordained; a young gentleman being spent, to have a rich widow set him up again: to see how fortune has provided for all mortality's ruins; your college for your old standing scholar, your hospital for your lame creeping soldier, your bawd for your mangled roarer, your open house for your beggar, and your widow for your gentleman: ha Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I sir, you may be merry: you're in hope of a rich widow.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: And why shouldst not thou be in hope of another, if there were any spirit in thee, thou art as likely a fellow as any is in the company. I'll be hanged now if I do not hit the true cause of thy sadness; and confess truly i'faith; thou hast some land unsold yet, I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Marry I hope so sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: A pox on't, have I found it? 'slight away with't with all speed man. I was never merry at heart while I had a foot: why man, fortune never minds us, till we are left alone to ourselves: for what need she take care for them, that do nothing but take care for themselves? why, dost think if I had kept my lands still, I should ever have looked after a rich widow? alas, I should have married some poor young maid, got five and twenty children, and undone myself.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I protest sir, I should not have the face though, to come to a rich widow with nothing

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Why, art thou so simple, as thou mak'st thyself? dost think i'faith I come to a rich widow with nothing?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I mean with state not answerable to hers.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why there's the fortune, man, that I talked on;
She knows all this, and yet I am welcome to her.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I ▪ that's strange sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Nay more to pierce thy hard heart, and make thee sell thy land if thou'st any grace: she has 'mongst others two substantial suitors,
sp.l: One, in good time be't spoke, I owe much money to,
She knows this too, and yet I'm welcome to her,
Nor dares the unconscionable rascal trouble me;
Sh'as told him thus, those that profess love to her
Shall have the liberty to come and go,
Or else get him gone first; she knows not yet
Where fortune may bestow her, she's her gift,
Therefore to all will show a kind respect.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why this is like a woman: I ha' no luck in't.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: And as at a sheriff's table, oh blessed custom,
A poor indebted gentleman may dine,
Feed well, and without fear, and depart so,
So to her lips, fearless I come and go?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You may well boast, you're much the happier man sir

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So you would be, and you would sell your land sir

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I have heard the circumstance of your sweet fortunes:
Prithee give ear to my unlucky tale now.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: That's an ill hearing; but come on for once sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I never yet loved but one woman.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Right, I begun so too; but I have loved a thousand since.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray hear me sir; but this is a man's wife.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So has five hundred of my thousand been.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay see and you'll regard me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: No? you see I do,
I bring you an example in for every thing.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This man's wife

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So you said.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Seems very strict

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ha, humh.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do you laugh at that?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Seems very strict you said,
I hear you man, i'faith you are so jealous still.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But why should that make you laugh?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Because she seems so: you're such another —

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay sir, I think she is.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: You cannot tell then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I dare not ask the question I protest
For fear of a repulse, which yet not having.
My mind's the quieter, and I live in hope still.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ha, hum: this 'tis to be a landed man. Come, I perceive
I must show you a little of my fortune, and instruct you:
Not ask the question?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Methought still she frowned sir?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why that's the cause fool, that she looked so scurvily.
Come, come, make me your woman, you'll ne'er do't else,
I'll show you her condition presently.
sp.p: I perceive you must begin like a young vaulter, and get up at horse-tail, before you get into the saddle; have you the boldness to utter your mind to me now, being but in hose and doublet? I think if I should put on a farthingale, thou wouldst never have the heart to do't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Perhaps I should not then for laughing at you sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: In the mean time I fear I shall laugh at thee without one.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay you must think friend, I dare speak to a woman.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: You shall pardon me for that friend; I will not think it,
Till I see't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Why you shall then: I shall be glad to learn too, of one so deep as you are.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: So you may sir; now 'tis my best course to look mildly, I shall put him out at first else.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A word, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: With me sir? say your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O Ricardo,
Thou art too good to be a woman long.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Do not find fault with this, for fear I prove
Too scornful, be content when you're well used.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You say well sir. Lady I have loved you long.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Tis a good hearing sir. If he be not out now I'll be hanged.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You play a scornful woman? I perceive Ricardo, you have not been used to 'em: why I'll come in at my pleasure with you: alas 'tis nothing for a man to talk, when a woman gives way to't: one shall seldom meet with a lady so kind, as thou play'dst her.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Not altogether perhaps: he that draws their pictures must flatter 'em a little, they'll look he that plays 'em should do't a great deal then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Come, come I'll play the woman, that I'm used too,
I see you ne'er wore shoe that pinched you yet,
All your things comes on easy.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Say you so sir?
I'll try your ladyship i'faith: lady well met.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I do not think so sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A scornful gom,
sp.p: And at the first dash too: my widow never gave me such an answer, I'll to you again sir.
sp.l: Fairest of creatures, I do love thee infinitely.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: There's nobody bids you sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Pox on thee thou art the beastliest crossest baggage that ever man met withal; but I'll see thee hanged sweet lady ere I be daunted with this: why thou'rt too awkward sirrah.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Hang thee base fellow.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now by this light, he thinks he dost indeed,
Nay then have at your plumb-tree faith, I'll not be foiled,
sp.p: Though you seem to be careless madam, as you have enough wherewith all to be, yet I do, must, and will love you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, if you begin to be rude, I'll call my woman.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: What a pestilent queans this? I shall have much ado with her I see that; tell me as you're a woman lady, what serve kisses for? but to stop all your mouths.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Hold, hold Ricardo.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Disgrace me widow.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Ait mad, I'm Francisco?

sp.speaker: Atta.
sp.l: Signior Ricardo, up, up.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Who is't Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Francisco quoth 'a? what are you mad sir?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: A bots on thee, thou dost not know what injury thou hast done me, I was i'th' fairest dream, this is your way now, and you can follow it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis a strange way methinks .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Learn you to play a woman not so scornfully then,
For I am like the actor that you spoke on,
I must have the part that overcomes the lady,
I never like the play else. — now your friendship,
But to assist a subtle trick I ha' thought on,
And the rich widows mine within these three hours.

sp.speaker: Att. Fra.
sp.l: We should be proud of that sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: List to me then.
I'll place you too, I can do't handsomely
I know the house so well, to hear the conference
Betwixt her and I, she's a most affable one,
Her words will give advantage, and I'll urge 'em
To the kind proof, to catch her in a contract,
Then shall you both step in as witnesses,
And take her in the snare.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But do you love her?
And then 'twill prosper.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: By this hand I do,
Not for her wealth, but for her person too.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It shall be done then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But stay, stay Francisco,
Where shall we meet with thee some two hours hence now?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why hark you sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Enough, command my life,
Get me the widow, I'll get thee the wife.

sp.speaker: Fra
sp.l: O that's now with me passed hope; yet I must love her,
I would I could not do't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yonder's the villain master.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Francisco; I am happy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Let's both draw Mr. for there's nobody with him; stay, stay Mr.
sp.l: Do not you draw till I be ready too,
Let's draw just both together, and keep e'en.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: What and we killed him now, before he saw us?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, than he will hardly see to read the letter.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: That's true: good counsel marry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Marry thus much sir, you may kill him lawfully, all the while he's a reading on't, as an Anabaptist may lie with a brother's wife, all the while he's asleep .

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: He turns; he looks: come on sir, you, Francisco,
I loved your father well, but you're a villain:
He loved me well too; but you love my wife sir,
After whom take you that? I will not say
Your mother played false.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: No sir, you were not best.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: But I will say, in spite of thee, my wife's honest.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I, my mistress.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You may, I'll give you leave.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Leave, or leave not, there, she defies you sir;
Keep your adulterous sheet to wind you in,
Or cover your forbidden parts at least,
For fear you want one; many a lecher may
That sins in cambric now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And in lawn too master.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Nay read, and tremble sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now shall I do't Mr.? I see a piece of an open seam in his shirt, shall I run him in there, for my sword has ne'er a point.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: No, let him foam a while.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If your sword be no better than mine, we shall not kill him by daylight, we had need have a lantern.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Talk not of lanterns, he's a sturdy lecher,
He would make the horns fly about my ears.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I apprehend thee: admirable woman,
Which to love best I know not; thy wit, or beauty.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Now sir, have you well viewed your bastard there,
Got of your lustful brain? give you joy on't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I thank you sir, although you speak in jest,
I must confess, I sent your wife this letter,
And often courted her, tempted, and urged her.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Did you so sir?
Then first before I kill thee, I forewarn thee my house ▪

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I before I kill thee, forewarn thee my office; die tomorrow next, thou never gettest warrant of me more, for love, or money.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Remember but again, from whence I came sir,
And then I know you cannot think amiss of me.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray hear him: it may grow to a peace:
sp.p: For Mr. though we have carried the business nobly, we are not altogether so valiant as we should be.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Peace, thou sayest true in that: what is't you'd say sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Was not my father, (Quietness be with him)
And you sworn brothers?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why right: that's it urges me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And could you have a thought that I could wrong you,
As far as the deed goes?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: You took the course sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To make you happy, and you rightly weighed it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Troth I'll put up at all adventures Mr.
It comes off very fair yet.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You in years
Married a young maid: what does the world judge think you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By’r lady Mr. knavishly enough I warrant you,
I should do so myself.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Now to damp slander,
And all her envious and suspicious brood,
I made this friendly trial of her constancy,
Being son to him you loved; that now confirmed
I might advance my sword against the world
In her most fair defence, which joys my spirit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Mr. let me weep while you embrace him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Francisco; is thy father's soul in thee?
Lives he here still? what, will he show himself
In his male seed to me? give me thy hand,
Methinks it feels now like thy fathers to me,
Prithee forgive me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And me to, prithee.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Come to my house, thy father never missed it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fetch now as many warrants as you please sir,
And welcome too.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To see how soon man's goodness
May be abused.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: But now I know thy intent
Welcome to all that I have.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, I take it:
A gift so given, hang him that would forsake it.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Martino, I applaud my fortune, and thy counsel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You never have ill fortune when you follow it.
Here was things carried now, in the true nature of a quiet duello;
A great strife ended, without the rough soldier, or the —
And now you may take your journey.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Thou art my glee Martino.

div.head: Actus 2. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter Valeria the widow and a servant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Servellio.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If that fellow come again,
Answer him without me: I'll not speak with him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He in the nutmeg-coloured band forsooth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ay, that spiced-coxcomb sir: never may I marry again
If his right worshipful idolatrous face
Be not most fearfully painted, painted, so hope comfort me,
I might perceive it peel in many places,
And under's eye, lay a betraying foulness,
As maids sweep dust o'th' house, all to one corner,
It showed me enough there, prodigious pride
That cannot but fall scornfully. I'm a woman,
Yet I praise heaven, I never had the ambition
To go about to mend a better workman,
She ever shames herself i'th' end, that does it.
He that likes me not now, as heaven made me,
I will never hazard hell to do him a pleasure;
Nor lie every night like a woodcock in past
To please some gaudy goose i'th' morning:
A wise man likes that best, that is itself,
Not that which only seems, though it look fairer;
Heaven send me one that loves me, and I'm happy,
Of whom I'll make great trial ere I have him,
Though I speak all men fair, and promise sweetly,
I learn that of my suitors, 'tis their own,
Therefore injustice 'twere to keep it from'em .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: And so as I said sweet widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do you begin where you left sir?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I always desire when I come to a window, to begin i'th' middle of a sentence, for I presume she has a bad memory of a woman that cannot remember what goes before.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Stay, stay sir, let me look upon you well,
Are not you painted too?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: How, painted, widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not painted widow, I do not use it trust me sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: That makes me love thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I mean painted gentleman,
Or if you please to give him a greater style sir;
Blame me not sir, it's a dangerous age I tell you,
Poor simple dealing women had need look about 'em.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But is there such a fellow in the world, widow,
As you are pleased to talk on?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, here lately sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Here? A pox, I think I smell him, 'tis vermilion sure, ha: oil of Ben, do but show him me widow, and let me never hope for comfort, if I do not immediately geld him, and grind his face upon one o'th' stones.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Suffices you've expressed me your love and valour, and manly hate against that unmanly pride: but sir, I'll save you that labour, he never comes within my door again.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
I'll love your door the better while I know't widow; a pair of such brothers were fitter for posts without door indeed, to make a show at a new-chosen magistrates gate, than to be used in a woman's chamber: no, sweet widow, having me, you've
the truth of a man, all that you see of me, is full mine own, and what you see, or not see, shall be yours: I ever hated to be beholding to art, or to borrow any thing but money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: True, and that you never use to pay again.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What matter is't? if you be pleased to do't
For me, I hold it as good.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O, soft you sir I pray.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why 'I'faith you may and you will.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know that sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Troth, and I would have my will then if I were as you.
There's few women else but has.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But since I cannot have't in all signior, I care not to have it in any thing.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why you may have't in all, and you will widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pish, I would have one that loves me for myself sir,
Not for my wealth: and that I cannot have.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What say you to him that does the thing you wish for?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why here's my hand, I'll marry none but him then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Your hand, and faith.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My hand, and faith.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Tis I then.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I shall be glad on't trust me: shrew my heart else.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A match.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Give you joy, sweet widow.

sp.speaker: At.
sp.l: Joy to you both.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Nay, there's no starting now, I have you fast widow,
You're witness gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fra. Att.
sp.l: We'll be deposed on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Am I betrayed to this then? than I see
'Tis for my wealth; a woman's wealth's her traitor.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Tis for love chiefly, I protest sweet widow,
I count wealth but a fiddle to make us merry.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hence.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why thou'rt mine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I do renounce it utterly.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Have I not hand and faith?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, take your course.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: With all my heart; ten courses and you will widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, sir, I'm not so gamesome as you think me,
I'll stand you out by law.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: By law? O cruel merciless woman,
To talk of law, and know I have no money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will consume myself to the last stamp,
Before thou get'st me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: 'Life, I'll be as wilful then too: I'll rob all the carriers in Christendom, but I'll have thee, and find my lawyer's money:
sp.l: I scorn to get thee under forma pauperis,
I have too proud a heart, and love thee better.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As for you gentlemen, I'll take course against you;
You came into my house without my leave;
Your practises are cunning, and deceitful;
I know you not, and I hope law will right me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: It is sufficient that your husband knows 'em,
'Tis not your business to know every man,
An honest wife contents herself with one.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You know what you shall trust to, pray depart sir,
And take your rude confederates along with you,
Or I will send for those shall force your absence:
I'm glad I found your purpose out so soon.
How quickly may poor women be undone.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Lose thee? by this hand I'll fee fifteen counsellors first, though I undo a hundred poor men for 'em, and I'll make 'em yaul one another deaf, but I'll have thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Me?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ay, fret thy heart out.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Were I he now
I'd see thee starve for man before I had thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pray counsel him to that sir, and I'll pay you well.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pay me? pay your next husband.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do not scorn't gallant: a worse woman than I,
Has paid a better man than you.

div.l: 1 why how now sweet widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O kind gentlemen,
I am so abused here.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Abused?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What will you do sirs? put up your weapons.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.p:
Nay, they're not so easily drawn, that I must tell you
you, mine has not been out this three ears; marry in your cause widow, 'twould not be long a drawing. Abused? by whom widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, by a beggar.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.p: A beggar? I'll have him whipped then, and sent to the house of correction.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ricardo? Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.p: Ricardo? nay by th' mass, he's a gentleman beggar, he'll be hanged before he be whipped. Why you'll give me leave to clap him up I hope?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis too good for him; that's the thing he would have,
He would be clapped up whether I would or no methinks;
Placed two of his companions privately,
Unknown to me, on purpose to entrap me
In my kind answers, and at last stole from me,
That which I fear will put me to some trouble,
A kind of verbal courtesy, which his witnesses
And he forsooth call by the name of contract.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: O politic villain,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But I am resolved gentlemen,
If the whole power of my estate can cast him,
He never shall obtain me.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Hold you there widow,
Well fare your heart for that i'faith.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Stay, stay, stay,
You broke no gold between you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We broke nothing sir.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Nor drunk to one another?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not a drop sir.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: You're sure of this you speak?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Most certain sir.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Be of good comfort wench, I'll undertake then
At mine own charge to overthrow him for thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O do but that sir, and you bind me to you,
Here shall I try your goodness. I'm but a woman,
And alas, ignorant in law businesses,
I'll bear the charge most willingly.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Not a penny,
Thy love will reward me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And where love must be,
it is all but one purse now I think on't.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: All comes to one, sweet widow.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Are you so forward?

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: I know his mates Attilio and Francisco,
I'll get out process and and attach 'em all,
We'll begin first with them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I like that, strangely.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: I have a daughter run away I thank her,
I'll be a scourge to all youth for her sake:
Some of 'em has got her up.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your daughter? what sir? Martia.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: I a shake wed her,
I would have married her to a wealthy gentleman,
No older than myself, she was like to be shrewdly hurt widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It was too happy for her.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: I'm of thy mind.
Farewell sweet widow, I'll about this strait,
I'll have 'em all three put into one writ,
And so save charges.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How I love your providence.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Is my nose board? I'll cross ye both for this,
Although it cost me as much o'th' other side,
I have enough, and I will have my humour.
I may get out of her, what may undo her too;
Hark you sweet widow, you must now take heed,
You be of a sure ground, he'll overthrow your else.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Marry fair hope forbid.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.p: That will he: marry le' me see, le' me see: pray how far passed it between you and Ricardo?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Farther sir
Than I would now it had, but I hope well yet.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Pray let me hear't: I've a shrewd guess o'th' law.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Faith sir, I rashly gave my hand and faith
To marry none but him.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ay, trust me sir.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: I'm very glad on't, I'm another witness,
And he shall have you now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What said you sir.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: He shall not want money in an honest cause widow,
I know I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Are all the world betrayers.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Pish, pish, widow.
You've born me in hand this three months, and now fobbed me
I've known the time when I could please a woman,
I'll not be laughed at now; when I'm crossed, I'm a tiger;
I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This only shows your malice to me sir,
The world knows you ha' small reason to help him,
So much in your debt already.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Therefore I do't,
I have no way but that to help myself;
Though I lose you, I will not lose all widow;
He marrying you, as I will follow't for him,
I'll make you pay his debts, or lie without him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I looked for this from you.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: I ha' not deceived you then:
Fret, vex, and chafe, I'm obstinate where I take.
I'll seek him out, and cheer him up, against her,
I ha' no charge at all, no child of mine own,
But two I got once of a scowring woman,
And they're both well provided for, they're i'th' hospital:
I have ten thousand pound to bury me, and I will have my humour.

div.head: Scaena 2.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A man must have a time to serve his pleasure,
As well as his dear friend, I'm forced to steal from 'em,
To get this night of sport for mine own use ▪
What says her amiable witty letter here?
Betwixt nine and ten, now 'tis 'twixt six and seven,
As fit as can be; he that follows lechery,
Leaves all at six and seven, and so do I methinks :
Sun sets at eight, it's above an hour high yet,
Some fifteen mile have I before I reach her,
But I've an excellent horse; and a good gallop,
Helps man as much as a provoking banquet.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Here's one of 'em, begin with him first officers.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: By virtue of this writ we attach your body sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My body? 'life, for what?

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Hold him fast officers.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: The least of us can do't, now his sword's off sir,
We have a trick of hanging upon gentlemen,
We never lose a man.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O treacherous fortune,
Why what's the cause?

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: The widow's business sir,
I hope you know me?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: For a busy coxcomb,
This fifteen year, I take it.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: O you're mad sir,
Simple though you make me, I stand for the widow.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: She's simply stood for then: what's this to me sir,
Or she, or you, or any of these flesh-hooks?

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: You're like to find good bail before you leave us,
Or lie till the suit's tried.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O my love's misery.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.p: I'm put in trust to follow't, and I'll do't with all severity;
sp.l: Build upon that sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How I would curse myself.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Look, here's Francisco,
Will you believe me, now you see his qualities?

sp.speaker: Attilio.
sp.l: 'Tis strange to me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I tell you 'tis his fashion,
He never stole away in's life from me,
But still I found him in such scurvy company;
A pox on thee Francisco wilt never leave thy old
Tricks, are these lousy companions for thee?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pish, pish, pish.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Here they be all three now: 'Apprehend 'em officers.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I gave you warning enough to make away,
I'm in for the widow's business, so are you now.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: What, all three in a noose? this is like a widow's business indeed.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Sh'as catched you gentlemen, as you catched her,
The widow means now, to begin with you sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p:
I thank her heartily, sh'as taught me wit: for had I been any but an ass, I should ha' begun with her indeed: by this light, the widows a notable housewife, she bestirs herself, I have a
greater mind to her now than e'er I had: I cannot go to prison for one I love better I protest, that's one good comfort, and what are you I pray sir, for a coxcomb?

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: It seems you know me by your anger sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I've a near guess at you sir.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Guess what you please sir,
I'm he ordained to trounce you, and indeed
I am the man must carry her.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ay, to me.
But I'll swear she's a beast, and she carry thee.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Come, where's your bail sir, quickly, or away.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Sir, I'm held wrongfully, my bail's taken already.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Where is't sir, where?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Here they be both: pox on you, they were taken before I'd need of 'em, and you be honest officers let's bail one another, for by this hand, I do not know who will else: — 'Odds' light is he come too? I'm in for midnight then, I shall never find the way out again: my debts, my debts:

div.l: I'm like to die i'th' hole now.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: We have him fast old signior, and his consorts,
Now you may lay action on action on him.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: That may I sir, i'faith.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: And I'd not spare him sir.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Know you me officers?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Your bounteous worship sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I know the rascal so well, I dare not look upon him.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Upon my worth deliver me that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Which gentleman?

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Not you sir, you're too hasty;
No, nor you neither sir: pray stay your time.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: There's all but I now, and I dare not think he means me.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Deliver me Ricardo.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: O sure he lies.
Or else I do not hear well.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Signior Ricardo.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Well, what's the matter? you may go, who let's you?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: It is his worship's pleasure sir to bail you.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Bail me?

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: I will, I sir, look in my face man,
Thou'st a good cause, thoul't pay me when thour't able?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ay, every penny, as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: No matter if thou dost not, then, I'll make thee,
And that's as good at all times.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: But I pray sir,
You go against the hair there.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Against the widow you mean sir,
Why 'tis my purpose truly, and against you too,
I saw your politic combination,
I was thrust out between you: here stands one
Shall do as much for you, and he stands rightest,
His cause is strong and fair, nor shall he want
Money, or means, or friends, but he shall have her,
I've enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Hang thee; I have a purse as good as thine.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I think they're much alike, they're rich knaves both.
'Heart, and I take your railing at my patron sir,
I'll cramp your joints.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Let him alone sweet honey,
I thank thee for thy love though.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: This is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O Ricardo,
'Tis seven, struck in my pocket: I lose time now.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What sayst Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I ha' mighty business,
That I ne'er thought on: get me bailed, I'm spoilt else.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why you know, 'tis such a strange miraculous courtesy,
I dare not be too forward, to ask more of him,
For fear he repent this, and turn me in again.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do somewhat and you love me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I'll make trial i'faith
May't please you sir: — 'life if I should spoil all now?

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: What sayst Ricardo?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Only a thing by th' way sir,
Use your own pleasure.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: That I like well from thee.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Twere good, and those two gentlemen were bailed too,
They're both my witnesses.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: They're well, they're well:
And they were bailed, we know not where to find 'em,
Let 'em go to prison, they'll be forthcoming the better,
I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I knew there was no more good to be done upon him,
'Tis well I've this, heaven knows I never looked for't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What plaguy luck had I to be ensnared thus?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: O, patience.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pox oh your comfortable ignorance.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Martino, we ride slow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But we ride sure sir,
Your hasty riders often come short home Mr.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: 'Bless this fair company.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Here he's again too,
I am both shamed, and crossed.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Seest thou who's yonder, Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We ride slow, I'll be sworn now Mr.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How now Francisco, art thou got before me?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, thank my fortune, I am got before you.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: What no? in hold?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ay, of my troth poor gentleman,
Your worship sir, may do a good deed to bail him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why do not you do't then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: La you sir now, my Mr. has that honesty
He's loath to take a good deed from you sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I'll tell you why I cannot, else I would sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Luck I beseech thee,
If he should be wrought to bail me now, to go to
His wife, 'twere happiness beyond expression.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: A matter but of controversy.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: That's all, trust me sir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Francisco shall ne'er lie for't; he's my friend,
And I will bail him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He's your secret friend Mr.
Think upon that.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Give him his liberty officers,
Upon my peril, he shall be forth coming.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How I am bound to you?

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Know you whom you cross sir?
'Tis at your sister's suit, be well advised sir,

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How, at my sister's suit? take him again then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why sir, do you refuse me?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I'll not hear thee.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: This is unkindly done sir.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: 'Tis wisely done sir.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Well shot, foul malice.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Flattery stinks worse sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: You'll never leave till I make you stink as bad sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O Martino, have I this for my late kindness?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas poor gentleman, dost complain to me?
Thou shalt not fare the worse for't: hark you master,
Your sister's suit said you?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Ay sir, my wife's sister.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And shall that daunt you master? think again,
Why were't your mother's suit; your mother's suit,
Mark what I say, the dearest suit of all suits,
You're bound in conscience sir to bail this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Yea, am I so, how provest thou that Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have you forgotten so soon, what he did lately?
Has he not tried your wife to your hand master?
To cut the throat of slander and suspicion;
And can you do too much for such a man?
Shall it be said, I serve an ingrateful master?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Never Martino; I will bail him now,
And 'twere at my wife's suit.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis like to be so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I his friend, to follow your example Mr.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Precious Martino.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: You've done wondrous well sir.
Your sister shall give you thanks.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: This makes him mad sir.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: We'll follow't now toth' proof.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Follow your humour out,
The widow shall find friends.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: And so shall he sir,
Money and means.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Hear you me that old huddle.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Mind him not, follow me and I'll supply thee,
Thou shalt give all thy lawyers double fees,
I've buried money enough to burry me,
And I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Fare thee well once again my dear Francisco,
I prithee use my house.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is my purpose sir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Nay you must do't then; though I am old, I'm free.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And when you want a warrant, come to me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That will be shortly now, within this few hours.
This fell out strangely happy. Now to horse,
I shall be nighted; but an hour or two
Never breaks square in love; he comes in time
That comes at all; absence is all love's crime.

div.head: Actus 3. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter Occulto, Silvio, and two or three other thieves.

sp.speaker: Occulto.
sp.l: Come, come, let's watch th'event on yonder hill,
If he need help, we can relieve him suddenly.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ay, and with safety too, the hill being watched sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Have you the blue coats and the beards?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: They're here sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Come, come away then, a fine cock shoot evening.

div.stage: Enter latrocinio the chief thief, and Ansoldo.

sp.speaker: La. sings.
sp.l: Kuck before, and kuck behind, &c. etc.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Troth you're the merriest, and delightfullest company sir,
That ever traveller was blessed withal,
I praise my fortune that I overtook you sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Pish, I've a hundred of 'em.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: And believe me sir,
I'm infinitely taken with such things.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I see there's music in you, you kept time methought
Pretty and handsomely with your little hand there.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: It only shows desire, but troth, no skill sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well, while our horses walk down yonder hill sir,
I'll have another for you.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: It rids way pleasantly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Le' me see now: one confounds another sir,
You've heard this certainly: come my dainty doxes.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O, that's all the country over sir,
There's scarce a gentlewoman, but has that pricked.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well, here comes one I'm sure you never heard then.
I keep my horse, I keep my whore,
I take no rends, yet am not poor;
I traverse all the land about,
And yet was born to never a foot:
With partridge plump, with woodcock fine
I do at midnight often dine;
And if my whore be not in case,
My hostess daughter has her place;
The maids sit up, and watch their turns,
If I stay long the tapster mourns;
The cookmaid has no mind to sin,
Though tempted by the chamber lin;
But when I knock, o how they bustle,
The ostler yawns, the geldings justle.
If maid but sleep, o how they curse her!
And all this comes of, deliver your purse sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Few words: quickly come, deliver your purse sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You're not that kind of gentleman, I hope sir,
To sing me out of my money?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Tis most fit
Art should be rewarded: you must pay your music sir
Where ere you come.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: But not at your own carving.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nor am I common in't: come, come your purse sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Say it should prove the undoing of a gentleman?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why sir, do you look for more conscience in us, than
In usurers? young gentleman, you've small reason for that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: There 'tis, and all I have; and so truth comfort me,
All I know where to have.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir, that's not written
In my belief yet; search, 'tis a fine evening,
Your horse can take no harm: I must have more sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: May my hopes perish, if you have not all sir,
And more I know than your compassionate charity
Would keep from me, if you but felt my wants.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Search, and that speedily: if I take you in hand,
you'll find me rough, methinks men should be ruled,
When they're so kindly spoken too, fie upon't.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Good fortune, and my wit assist me then,
A thing I took in haste, and never thought on't:
Look sir, I've searched, here's all that I can find,
And you're so covetous, you will have all you say,
And I'm content you shall, being kindly spoke too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A pox of that young devil of a handful long.
That 'As 'fraid many a tall thief from a rich purchase.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: This, and my money sir, keeps company;
Where one goes, th'other must; assure your soul
They vowed never to part.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hold, I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You rob a prisoner's box, and you rob me, sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There 'tis again.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I knew 't would never prosper with you;
Fie, rob a younger brother, o take heed sir,
'Tis against nature that, perhaps your father
Was one sir, or your uncle, it should seem so
By the small means was left you, and less manners.
Go, keep you still before me, and do you hear me;
To pass away the time to the next town,
I charge you sir, sing all your songs for nothing —

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: O horrible punishment. — a song:

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Honest gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: How now, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Stand you in need of help?
I made all haste I could, my master charged me.
A knight of worship; he saw you first assaulted.
From top of yonder hill.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Thanks honest friend.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I taste this trick already. —

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Look, he's gone sir,
Shall he be stopped; what is he?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Let him go sir;
He can rejoice in nothing, that's the comfort.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: You have your purse still then?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Ay, thanks fair fortune,
And this grim handful.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: We were all so 'fraid o'you,
How my good lady cried o help the gentleman,
'Tis a good woman that: but you're too mild sir,
You should ha' marked him for a villain i'faith
Before he'd gone, having so sound a means too.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Why there's the jest man; he had once my purse.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: O ▪ villain, would you let him scape unmassacred?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Nay, hear me sir, I made him yield it straight again,
And so hope bless me, with an uncharged pistol.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: 'Troth I should laugh at that.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: It was discharged sir,
Before I meddled with't.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I'm glad to hear't.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Why how now, what's your will?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Hoh, latrocinio, occulto, Silvio. —

div.stage: [enter latrocinio and the rest, Occulto, Silvio, Fiducio.]

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What are you caught sir?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: The pistol cannot speak.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He was too young,
I ever thought he could not; yet I feared him.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You've found out ways too merciless to betray
Under the veil of friendship, and of charity.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Away sirs, bear him in to th' next copse, and strip him.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Brandino's copse, the justice?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Best of all sit, a man of law?
A spider lies unsuspected in the corner of a buckram bag, man.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What seek you sirs? take all and use no cruelty,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You shall have songs enough.
How round the world goes, and every thing that's in it,
The tides of gold and silver, ebb and flow in a minute:
From the usurer to his sons, there a current swiftly runs,
From the sons to queans in chief, from the gallant to the thief,
From the thief unto his host, from the host to husbandmen;
From the country to the court, and so it comes to us again.
How round the world goes, and every thing that's in it,
The tides of gold and silver, ebb and flow in a minute.
sp.stage: Enter Philipp A and Violetta above at the window.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What time of night is't?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Time of night do you call't?
It's so late, 'tis almost early mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fie on him, there's no looking for him then;
Why sure this gentleman apprehends me not.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Tis happy then you're rid of such a fool mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay sure wench, if he find me not out in this
Which were a beaten path to any wiseman,
I'll never trust him with my reputation;
Therefore I made this trial of his wit,
If he cannot conceive what's good for himself,
He will worse understand what's good for me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But suppose Mrs. as it may be likely,
He never saw your letter?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How thou pliest me,
With suppositions? why I tell thee wench,
'Tis equally as impossible for my husband
To keep it from him, as to be young again,
Or as his first wife knew him, which he brags on
For bearing children by him.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: There's no remedy then,
I must conclude Francisco is an ass.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I would my letter, wench, were here again,
I'd know him wiser ere I sent him one;
And travail some five year first.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: So he'd need methinks,
To understand the words, methinks the words
Themselves should make him do't, had he but the perseverance
Of a cock sparrow, that will come at Philip,
And can nor write, nor read poor fool, this coxcomb
He can do both, and your names but Philippa,
And yet to see, if he can come when's called,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He never shall be called again for me sirrah.
Well, as hard as the world goes, we'll have a song wench ,
We'll not sit up for nothing.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: That's poor comfort though.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Better then any's brought, for ought I see yet? So set to your lute.
sp.l: 1 if in this question I propound to thee
Be any, any choice,
Let me have thy voice.
2 you shall most free.
I which hadst thou rather be
If thou might choose thy life,
A fools, a fool's mistress,
Or an old man's wife?
2 the choice is hard, I know not which is best,
One ill you're bound too, and I think that's least.
1 but being not bound, my dearest sweet,
I could shake off the other.
2 then as you lose your sport by one,
You lose your name by tother.
1 you counsel well, but love refuses,
What good counsel often chooses.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I ha' got myself unbound yet: merciless villains,
I never felt such hardness since life dwelled in me;
'Tis for my sins: that light in yonder window
That was my only comfort in the woods,
Which oft the trembling of a leaf would lose me,
Has brought me thus far, yet I cannot hope
For succour in this plight, the world's so pitiless,
And every one will fear or doubt me now:
To knock will be too bold, I'll to the gate,
And listen if I can hear any stirring.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Was ever man so crossed? no 'tis but sweat sure,
Or the dew dropping from the leaves above me,
I thought 'thad bled again: these wenching businesses
Are strange unlucky things, and fatal fooleries,
No mar'le so many gallants die ere thirty,
'Tis able to vex out a man's heart in five year,
The crosses that belong to't: first arrested,
That set me back two mangey hours at least,
Yet that's a thing my heat could have forgiven,
because arresting, in what kind soever,
Is a most gentlemanlike affliction:
But here, within a mile o'th' town forsooth,
And two mile off this place, when a man's oath
Might ha' been taken for his own security,
And his thoughts brisk, and set upon the business,
To light upon a roguy flight of thieves,
Pox on 'em, here's the length of one of their whistles,
But one of my dear rascals, I pursued so,
The gaol has him, and he shall bring ou'ts fellows:
Had ever young man's love such crooked fortune?
I'm glad I'm so near yet; the surgeon bade me too
Have a great care; I shall never think of that now.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: One of the thieves come back again? I'll stand close;
He dares not wrong me now, so near the house,
And call in vain 'tis, till I see him offer't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Life, what should that be? A prodigious thing
Stands just as I should enter, in that shape too,
Which always appears terrible.
Whate'er it be, it is made strong against me
By my ill purpose. For 'tis man's own sin
That puts on armour upon all his evils,
And gives them strength to strike him: were it less
Than what it is, my guilt would make it serve;
A wicked man's own shadow has distracted him:
Were this a business now to save an honour,
As 'tis to spoil one, I would pass this then
Stuck all hell's horrors i'thee: now I dare not.
Why may't not be the spirit of my father
That loved this man so well, whom I make haste
Now to abuse? And I have been crossed about it
Most fearfully hitherto, if I well think on't;
Scaped death but lately too, nay most miraculously;
And what does fond man venture all these ills for,
That may so sweetly rest in honest peace?
For that which being obtained, is as he was
To his own sense but removed nearer still
To death eternal: what delight has man
Now at this present, for his pleasant sin
Of yesterday's committing? Alas, 'tis vanished,
and nothing but the sting remains within him.
The kind man bailed me too; I will not do't now
And 'twere but only that: how blessed were man,
Might he but have his end appear still to him,
That he might read his actions i'th' event?
'T would make him write true, though he never meant.
Whose check soe'er thou art, fathers, or friends,
Or enemies, I thank thee, peace require thee;
Light, and the lighter mistress both farewell.
He keeps his promise best that breaks with hell.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: He's gone to call the rest, and makes all speed,
I'll knock whate'er befalls, to please my fears,
For no compassion can be less than theirs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He's come, he's come; o are you come at last sir?
Make little noise, away, he'll knock again else.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I should have been at I stria by daybreak too,
Near to Valeria's house the wealthy widows,
There waits one purposely to do me good.
What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O, you're a sweet gallant, this your hour?
Give me your hand; come, come sir, follow me,
I'll bring you to light presently: softly, softly sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I should ha' given him up to all my thoughts
The dullest young man, if he had not found it;
So short of apprehension, and so worthless,
He were not fit for woman's fellowship;
I've been at cost too for a banquet for him;
Why't would ha' killed my heart, and most specially
To think that man should ha' no more conceit;
I should ha' thought the worse on's wit for ever,
And blamed mine own for too much forwardness.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O mistress, mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How now, what's the news?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O, I was out of my wits for a minute and a half.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: They are scarce settled yet mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Do you ask that seriously?
Did you not hear me squeak?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How? sure thou'rt out of thy wits indeed.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O, I'm well now,
To what I was mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why where's the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: The gentleman's forthcoming, and a lovely one,
But not Francisco.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What sayest, not Francisco?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Pish, he's a coxcomb, think not on him mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's all this?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I've often heard you say, you'd rather have
A wise man in his shirt than a fool feathered,
And now fortune has sent you one, a sweet young gentleman,
Robbed e'en to nothing but what first he brought with him,
The slaves had stripped him to th' very shirt mistress,
I think it was a shirt, I know not well,
For gallants wear both now adays.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But for a face, a hand, and as much skin
As I durst look upon, he's a most sweet one;
Francisco is a child of Egypt to him:
I could not but in pity to th' poor gentleman,
Fetch him down one of my old master's suits.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Twas charitably done,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You'd say mistress, if you had seen him as I did.
Sweet youth, I'll be sworn mistress he's the loveliest
Proper'st young gentleman, and so you'll say yourself,
If my master's clothes do not spoil him, that's all the fear now,
I would't had been your luck to have seen him
Without 'em, but for scarring on you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Go, prithee fetch him in whom thou commendest so,

div.l: Since fortune sends him surely we'll make much on him;
And better he deserves our love, and welcome,
Than the respectless fellow 'twas prepared for;
Yet if he please mine ease never so happily,
I will have trial of his wit, and faith,
Before I make him partner with my honour,
'Twas just Francisco's case, and he deceived me;
I'll take more heed o'th' next for't; perhaps now
To furnish his distress, he will appear
Full of fair promising courtship; but I'll prove him then
For a next meeting, when he needs me not,
and see what he performs then when the storm
Of his so rude misfortunes is blown over,
And he himself again: a distressed man's flatteries
Are like vows made in drink, or bonds in prison,
There's poor assurance in 'em: when he's from me,
And in's own power, than I shall see his love.
'Mass here he comes.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Never was star-crossed gentleman
More happy in a courteous virgin's love,
Than I in yours.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'm sorry they're no better for you,
I wished 'em handsomer, and more in fashion,
But truly sir, our house affords it not:
There is a suit of our clerks, hangs i'th' garret,
But that's far worse than this, if I may judge
With modesty of men's matters.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I deserve not
This, dear, and kind gentlewoman, is yond your mistress?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why trust me, here's my husband young again,
It is no sin to welcome you, sweet gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I am so much indebted, courteous lady,
To the unmatched charity of your house,
My thanks are such poor things they would but shame me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Beshrew thy heart for bringing o'him: I fear me
I have found wit enough already in him,
If I could truly but resolve myself
My husband was thus handsome at nineteen,
'Troth I should think the better of him at fourscore now.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Nay mistress, what would he be, were he in fashion,
A hempen curse on those that put him out on't,
That now appears so handsome, and so comely in clothes
Able to make a man an unbeliever,
And good for nothing but for shift, or so
If a man chance to fall i'th' ditch with better?
This is the best, that ever I marked in 'em,
A man may make him ready in such clothes
Without a candle.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I for shame of himself wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My master does it oft in winter mornings,
And never sees himself till he be ready.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No, nor then neither, as he should do wench.
I am sorry gentle sir, we cannot show you
A courtesy, in all points answerable
To your undoubted worth: your name I crave sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Ansaldo, lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis a noble name sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: The most unfortunate now.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: So do I think truly
As long as that suits on.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The most unfitting,
And unprovidest sir of all our courtesies,
I do presume is that you've passed already,
Your pardon but for that, and we're encouraged.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My faithful service, lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Please you sir
To taste the next a poor slight banquet, for sure I think you were ▪
Unluckily prevented of your supper sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My fortune makes me more than amends lady,
In your sweet kindness, which so nobly shown to me,
It makes me bold to speak my occasions to you:
I am this morning, that with cleverness now
So cheerfully hastens me, to meet a friend
Upon my states establishing, and the place
Ten mile from hence: o, I am forced unwillingly
To crave your leave for't, which done I return
In service plentiful.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is't so important?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: If I should fail, as much as my undoing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I think too well of you, to undo you sir,
Upon this small acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My great happiness.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But when should I be sure of you here again sir?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: As fast as speed can possibly return me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You will not fail?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: May never wish go well with me then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: There's to bear charges sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Courtesy dwells in you.
I brought my horse up with me from the woods,
that's all the good they left me, 'gainst their wills too,
May your kind breast never want comfort lady,
But still supplied, as liberally as you give.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Farewell sir, and be faithful.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Time shall prove me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: In my opinion now, this young man's likeliest
To keep his word, he's modest, wise, and courteous;
He has the language of an honest soul in him:
A woman's reputation may lie safe there,
I'm much deceived else, has a faithful eye
If it be well observed.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Good speed be with thee sir;
He puts him to't i'faith.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Violetta.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Alas, what have we done wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: What's the matter mistress?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Run, run, call him again; he must stay tell him;
Though it be upon's undoing, we're undone else,
Your master's clothes, their known the country over.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Now by this light that's true, and well remembered,
But there's no calling of him, he's out of sight now.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O what will people think?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: What can they think mistress?
The gentleman has the worst on't: were I he now
I'd make this ten mile, forty mile about
Before I'd ride through any market town with 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Will he be careful think'st?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My life for yours mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I shall long mightily to see him again.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And so shall I, I shall never laugh till then.

div.head: Actus 4. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter Ricardo and 2 suitor at one door, and Valeria, and 1 suitor at another door.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: It goes well hitherto, my sweet protector.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Ay, and shall still to th' end, to th' end my honey,
Wherefore have I enough, but to have't go well sir?

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: My whole state on't; thou overthrow'st him widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I hope well still sir.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Hope? be certain wench:
I make no question now, but thou art mine,
As sure as if I had thee in thy night-gear.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By'r lady, that I doubt sir.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: O 'tis clear wench
By one thing that I marked.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What's that good sweet sir?

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: A thing that never failed me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good sir, what?

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: I heard our counsellor speak a word of comfort
Invita voluntate, hah, that's he wench,
The word of words, the precious chiefy's faith.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Invita voluntate, what's the meaning sir?

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Nay there I leave you, but assure you thus much,
I never heard him speak that word i' my life,
But the cause went on's side, that I market ever.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Do, do, and spare not: thou wouldst talk with her.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Yes, with your leave, and liking.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Do, my adoption,
My chosen child, and thou holdest so obedient
Sure thou wilt live, and cozen all my kindred.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A child's part in your love, that's my ambition sir.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Go, and deserve it then: please me well now;
I love wrangling a life boy; there's my delight,
I have no other venery but vexation,
That's all my honey now: smartly now to her,
I've enough and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: This need not ha' been widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You say right sir.
No, nor your treachery, your close conspiracy
Against me for my wealth, need not ha' been neither.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I had your fairly, I scorn treachery
To your woman that I never meant to marry,
Much more to you whom I reserved for wife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How, wise?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ay, wife, wife, widow, be not ashamed on't,
It's the best calling ever woman came to,
And all your grace indeed, brag as you list.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I grant you sir, but not to be your wife.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: O, o.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Not mine? I think 'tis the best bargain
That ere thou madest i'thy life, or ever shall again,
When my heads laid: but that's not yet this threescore year,
Let's talk of nearer matters.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You're as near sir
As ere you're like to be, if law can right me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now before conscience, you're a wilful housewife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ay, and I fear you spend my goods lavishly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your goods?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I shall miss much I doubt me,
When I come to look over the inventory.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll give you my word you shall sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Look to't widow,
A night may come will call you to account for't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O if you had me now sir in this heat
I do but think how you'd be revenged on me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ay, may I perish else; if I would not get
Three children at a birth, and I could o'thee.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Take off your youngster there.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Take off your widow first,
He shall have the last word, I pay for't dear;
To her again sweet boy, that sides the weaker.
I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O brother see I'm up to th' ears in law here;
Look, copy upon copy.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: 'Twere grief enough if a man did but hear on't
But I'm in pain to see't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What sore eyes still brother?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Worse, and worse sister; the old woman's water
Does me no good.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, 't'as helped many sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It helps not me I'm sure — marti, o, o.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What ails Martino too?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, o, the toothache, the toothache.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Ah poor worm, this he endures for me now.
There beats not a more mutual pulse of passion,
In a kind husband when his wife breeds child,
