Than in Martino; I ha' marked it ever,
He breeds all my pains in's teeth still: and to quit me,
It is his eye-tooth too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ay, ay, ay, I.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where did I hear late of a skilful fellow,
Good for all kind of maladies? true, true sir,
His flag hangs out in town here, i'th' cross inn,
With admirable cures of all conditions,
It shows him a great travelling, and learned empiric.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: We'll both to him Martino.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hark you brother,
Perhaps you may prevail, as one indifferent.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Ay, about that sweet widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: True; speak low sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Well, what's the business, say, say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Marry this brother.
Call the young man aside, from the old wolf there,
And whisper in his ear a thousand dollars
If he will vanish, and let fall the suit,
And never put's to no more cost and trouble.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Say me those words good sir, I'll make 'em worth
A chain of gold to you, at your sister's wedding.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I shall do much for that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Welcome sweet heart,
Thou comest most happily, I'm bold to send for thee
To make a purpose good.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I take delight forsooth
In any such employment.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: 'Good wench trust me

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: How sir, let fall the suit? 'life I'll go naked first.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A thousand dollars sir, think upon them.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why they're but a thousand dollars, when they're thought on.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A good round sum.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A good round widow's better,
There's meat and money too. I have been bought
Out of my lands, and yielded, but (Sir) scorn
To be bought out of my affection.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why here's even just my university spirit,
I prized a piece of red deer, above gold then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: My patron would be mad, and he should hear on't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I pray what's good sir, for a wicked tooth?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Hanged, drawn, and quartering; is't a hollow one?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I 'tis a hollow one.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Then take the powder
Of a burned warrant, mixed with oil of felon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why sure you mock me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'Troth I think I do sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.l: Come hither honey; what's the news in whispers?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: He will not be bought out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No? that's strange brother.
Pray take a little pains about this project then,
And try what that effects.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I like this better;
Look you sweet gentles, see what I produce here
For amity's sake, and peace, to end all controversy;
This gentlewoman my charge left by her friends,
Whom for her person, and her portion,
I could bestow most richly, but in pity
To her affection, which lies bent at you sir,
I am content to yield to her desire.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: At me?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: But for this jar, 't had ne'er been offered.
I bring you flesh, and money, a rich heir,
And a maid too, and that's a thing worth thanks, sir:
Nay, one that has rid fifteen mile this morning
For your love only.

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.l: Honey, harken after her;
Being rich, I can have all my money there:
Ease my purse well, and never wage law further.
I have enough, yet I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Do you love me forsooth?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O infinitely.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I do not ask thee, that I meant to have thee,
But only to know what came in thy head to love me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My time was come sir, that's all I can say.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Alas poor soul, where didst thou love me first prithee?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: In happy hour be't spoke, out at a window sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A window? prithee clap it too, and call it in again:
What was I doing then should make thee love me?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Twirling your bandstring, which methought became you so generously well.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: 'Twas a good quality to choose a husband for: that love was likely to be tied in matrimony, that begun in a bandstring: yet I ha' known as come to pass ere now upon a tassel. Fare you well sister; I may be cozened in a maid, I cannot in a widow.

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.l: Art thou come home again; stickst thou there still?
I will defend thee still then.

sp.speaker: 1. Suter.
sp.l: Sir you malice
Will have enough on't.

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.l: I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: 1. Sut.
sp.l: Beggary will prove the sponge.

sp.speaker: 2. Sut.
sp.l: Sponge i' thy gascoyns,
Thy gally-gascoyns there.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ha brave protector.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I thought 'twould come to open wars again,
Let 'em agree as they will; two testy fops,
I'll have a care of mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ay, of my chops.

div.head: Scaena 2.
div.stage: Enter latrocinio and Occulto, (A banner of cures and diseases hung out.)

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Away, out with the banner, send 's good luck today.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: I warrant you; your name's spread sir, for an empiric.
There's an old mason troubled with the stone,
Has sent to you this morning for your counsel,
He would have ease fain.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Marry I cannot blame him sir.
But how he will come by't, there lies the question,

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: You must do somewhat sir, for he's swollen most piteously,
Has urine in him now was brewed last march.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Twill be rich gear for dyers.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: I would 'twere come to that sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Le' me see, I'll send him a whole musket-charge of gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Gunpowder? what sir, to break the stone?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I by my faith sir,
It is the likeliest thing I know to do't,
I'm sure it breaks stonewalls, and castles down,
I see no reason, but't should break the stone.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Nay, use you pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Troth, if that do not
I ha' nothing else that will.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: I know that too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why then thou'rt a coxcomb to make question on't.
Go call in all the rest, I have employment for them.
When the highways grow thin with travellers,
And few portmantues stirring, as all trades
Have their dead time we see; thee very, poor takings,
And lechery cold doings, and so forwards still;
Then do I take my inn, and those curmudgeons,
Whose purses I can never get abroad,
I take 'em at more ease here i' my chamber,
And make 'em come to me, it's more statelike too:
Hang him that has but one way to his trade,
He's like a mouth that eats but on one side,
And half cozens his belly, specially if he dine among shavers,
sp.stage: Enter all the rest Silvio, Stratio, Fiducio.
sp.l: And both-handed feeders: Stratio, Silvio, and Fiducio,
I will have none left out, there's parts for you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: For us? pray let's have 'em.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Change yourselves
With all speed possible into several shapes
Far from your own, as you a farmer sir,
A grazier you, and you may be a miller.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: O no, a miller comes too near a thief,
That may spoil all again.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Some country tailor then.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: That's near enough by'r lady, yet I'll venture that;
The miller's a white devil, he wears his theft
like innocence in badges most apparently
Upon his nose, sometimes between his lips;
The tailor modestly between his legs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why pray, do you present that modest thief then,
And hark you, for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Twill improve you sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Twill get believers, believe that my masters,
Repute and confidence, and make all things clearer;
When you see any come, repair you to me
As samples of my skill; there are few arts
But have their shadows sirs to set 'em off;
Then where the art itself is but a shadow
What need is there my friends? make haste away sirs.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Where are you sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Not far man; what's the news?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: The old justice sir, whom we robbed once by moonlight,
And bound his man and he in haycock-time
With a rope made of horse-meat, and in pity
Left their mares by 'em, which I think ere midnight
Did eat their hay-bound masters both at liberty, —

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Life, what of him man?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: He's enquiring earnestly
For the great man of art; indeed for you sir:
Therefore withdraw sweet sir; make yourself dainty now,
And that's three parts of any profession.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I have enough on't.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: How now, what thing's this?
Now by this light, the second part o'th' justice
Newly revived with never a hair on's face,
It should be the first rather by his smoothness,
But I ha' known the first part written last:
'Tis he, or let me perish, the young gentleman
We robbed, and stripped, but I am far from knowledge now.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: One word I pray sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: With me gentle sir?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Was there not lately seen about these parts sir
A knot of fellows, whose conditions
Are privily suspected?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Why do you ask sir?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: There was a poor young gentleman robbed last night.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Robbed?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Script of all i'faith.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: O beastly rascals.
Alas what was he?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Look o'me, and know him sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Hard-hearted villains, strip? troth when I saw you
Methought those clothes were never made for you sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Want made me glad of 'em.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: 'Send you better fortune's sir:
That we may have about with you once again.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I thank you for your wish of love, kind sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: 'Tis with my heart i'faith; now store of coin
And better clothes be with you.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: There's some honest yet
And charitably minded: how, what's here to do?
Here within this place is cured
All the griefs that were e'er endured.
Nay there thou liest, I endured one last night,
Thou canst not cure this morning; a strange promiser.
Palsy, gout, hydropic humour,
Breath that sticks beyond perfumer,
Fistula in ano, ulcer, megrim,
Or what disease soe'er beleaguer 'em,
Stone, rupture, squinancy, imposthuma,
Yet too dear it shall not cost 'em.
That's constionably said i'faith.
In brief, you cannot I assure you
Be unsound so fast, as I can cure you.
By'r lady, you shall pardon me, I'll not try't sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Martino, is not yond my hinder parts?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and your fore parts too sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I trow so,
I never saw my hind parts in my life else,
No, nor my fore ones neither: what are you sir?
Are you a justice pray?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: A justice? no truly.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: How came this suit to you then?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: How, this suit?
Why must he needs be a justice sir, that wears it?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You'll find it so: 'twas made for nobody else.
I paid for't.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O strange fortune, I have undone
The charitable woman.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: He'll be gone.
Martino, hold him fast, I'll call for aid.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Hold me? o curse of fate!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Mr., Mr.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What ails Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In my conscience
Has beat out the wrong tooth, I feel it now,
Three degrees of.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O slave, spoilt a fine penman.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: He lacked good manners though: lay hands of me?
I scorn all the deserts, that belong to't.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why how now? what's the broil?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The man of art
I take you sir to be.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'm the professor
Of those slight cures you read of in the banner.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Our business was to you most skilful sir,
But in the way to you, right worshipful
I met a thief.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A thief?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: With my clothes on sir,
Let but the hose be searched, I'll pawn my life
There's yet the tailor's bill in one o'th' pockets,
And a white thimble that I found i' moon light,
Thou sawest me when I put it in Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oy, oy.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: O, has spoilt the worthiest clerk that ere drew warrant here.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir, you're a stranger, but I must deal plain with you,
That suit of clothes must needs come oddly to you.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I dare not say which way, that's my affliction.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Is not your worship's name signior Brandino sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It has been so, these threescore year and upwards.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I heard there was a robbery done last night
Near to your house.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You heard a truth then sir,
And I the man was robbed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ah that's too gross
Send him away for fear of farther mischief,
I do not like him, he's a cunning knave.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I want but aid.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Within there.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Seize upon that impudent thief.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Then hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Away;
I'll neither hear thee speak, nor wear those clothes again,
To prison with the varlet.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: How am I punished?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I'll make thee bring out all, before I leave thee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You've took an excellent course with this bold villain sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I am sworn for service to the commonwealth sir,
sp.l: What are these, learned sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O they're my patients.
Good morrow, gout, rupture, and palsy.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: 'Tis farewell gout almost, I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What no, you cannot part so soon, I hope?
You came but lately to me.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: But most happily,
I can go near to leap sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What you cannot?
Away I say, take heed, be not to venturous though,
I've had you but three days, remember that.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Those three are better than three hundred sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yet again?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Ease takes pleasure to be known sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You with the rupture there hernia in scrotum.
Pray let me see your space this morning, walk sir,
I'll take your distance straight: 'twas F. O. yesterday:
Ah sirrah, here's a simple alteration,
Secundo gradu, ye F. U. already,
Here's a most happy change; be of good comfort sir,
Your knees are come, within three inches now
Of one another; by tomorrow noon
I'll make 'em kiss, and justle.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Bless your worship.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You have a hundred prayers in a morning sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'faith we have a few to pass away the day with:
Tailor, you had a stitch.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: O good your worship
I have had none since easter: were I rid
But of this whoreson palsy, I were happy;
I cannot thread my needle.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No, that's hard,
I never marked so much.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: It comes by fits sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas poor man: what would your worship say now
To see me help this fellow at an instant?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: And make him firm from shaking?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: As a steeple,
From the disease on't.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: 'Tis to me miraculous.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You, with your whoremaster disease, come hither;
Here, take me this round glass, and hold it steadfast,
Yet more sir, yet I say; so.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Admirable.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go, live, and thread thy needle.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Here Martino:
Alas poor fool, his mouth is full of praises
And cannot utter 'em.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No, what's the malady?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The fury of a tooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A tooth? ha, ha,
I though't had been some gangrene, fistula,
Canker, or ramex.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No, 'It's enough as 'tis sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My man shall ease that straight, sit you down there sir,
Take the tooth sirrah, daintily, insensibly:
But what's your worship's malady, that's for me sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Marry pray look you sir: your worship's counsel
About mine eyes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sore eyes? that's nothing too sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: By'r lady I that fell it ▪ think it somewhat.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Have you no convulsions? pricking aches sir,
Ruptures, or apostemates?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No by my faith sir,
not do I desire to have 'em.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Those are cures,
There do I win my fame sir: quickly sirrah,
Reach me the eye-cup hither: do you make water well sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I'm all well there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You feel no grief i'th' kidney.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Sound, sound, sound sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O here's a breath sir, I must talk withal
One of these mornings.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: There I think i'faith,
I am to blame indeed, and my wife's words
Are come to pass sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, o, 'tis not that, 'tis not that.
It is the next beyond it; there, there, there.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: The best have their mistakings: now I'll fit you sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What's that sweet sir, that comforts with his coolness?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O sovereign gear: wink hard, and keep it in sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, o, o.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Nay, here he goes, one twitch more, and he comes sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Auh, ho.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Spit out ▪ I told you he was gone sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: How cheers Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, I can answer you now master,
I feel great ease sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: So do I Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'm rid of a sore burden, for my part master,
Of a scaled little one.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Please but your worship now
To take three drops of the rich water with you,
I'll undertake your man shall cure you sir
At twice i'your own chamber.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Shall he so sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I will uphold him in't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then will I do't sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How lively your man's now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O I'm so light methinks
Over I was.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What is't contents your worship?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: E'en what your worship please, I am not mercenary.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My purse is gone Martino.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How, your purse sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: 'Tis gone i'faith: I've been among some rascals.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And that's a thing
I ever gave you warning of master, you care not
What company you run into.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Lend me some money: chide me anon I pray thee.
A pox on 'em for vipers, they ha' sucked blood o'me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O master.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: How now man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My purse is gone too.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: How? I'll never take warning more of thee while I live then, thou art an hypocrite, and art not fit to give good counsel to thy master, that canst not keep from ill company thyself.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This is most strange sir: both your purses gone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, I'd my hand on mine, when I came in.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Are you but sure of that; o would you were.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As I'm of ease.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Then, they're both gone one way, be that your comfort.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I but what way's that sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: That close knave in your clothes has got 'em both,
'Tis well you've clapped him fast.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why that's impossible.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O tell not me sir: I ha' known purses gone,
And the thief stand, and look one full i'th' face,
As I may do your worship, and your man now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, that's most certain master.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I will make
That rascal in my clothes answer all this then,
And all the robberies that have been done
Since the moon changed; get you home first Martino,
And know if any of my wife's things are missing,
Or any more of mine: tell her he's taken,
And by that token he has taken both our purses.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's an ill token master.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That's all one sir,
She must have that or nothing, for I'm sure
The rascal has left nothing else for a token.
Begun, make haste again; and meet me part o'th' way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll hang the villain,
and 't were for nothing but the souse he gave me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Sir, I depart ashamed of my requital,
And leave this seal ring with you as a pledge
Of further thankfulness.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No, I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Indeed you shall sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O, your worship's word sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You shall have my word too, for a rare gentleman
As ere I met withal.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Clear sight be with you sir;
If conduit-water, and my hostess milk
That comes with the ninth child now, may afford it.
'Life, I feared none but thee, my villainous tooth-drawer,

sp.speaker: Occult.
sp.l: There was no fear of me; I've often told you
I was bound prentice to a barber once,
But ran away i'th' second year.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I marry,
That made thee give a pull at the wrong tooth.
And me afraid of thee: what have we there sirs?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Some threescore dollars i'th master's purse,
And sixteen in the clerks, a silver seal,
Two or three amber beads, and four blank warrants.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Warrants? where be they? the best news came yet.
'Mass here's his hand, and here's his seal I thank him,
This comes most luckily: one of our fellows
Was took last night, we'll set him first at liberty,
And other good boys after him: and if he
In th' old justice's suit, whom he robbed lately,
Will come off roundly, we'll set him free too.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: That were a good deed i'faith, we may in pity.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There's nothing done merely for pity now adays,
Money or ware must help too.

div.stage: Song, in parts by the thieves.

lg.l: Give me fortune, give me health,
Give me freedom, I'll get wealth.
When he has the wide world his?
He that has the devil in fee,
Can have but all, and so have we.
Give us fortune, give us health,
Give us freedom, we'll get wealth.
In every hamlet, town and city,
He has lands, that was born witty.

div.head: Actus 5. Scaena 1.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How well this gentleman keeps his promise too?
Sure there's no trust in man.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: They're all Francisco's,
That's my opinion mistress: fools, or false ones.
He might have had the honesty yet i'faith
To send my master's clothes home.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I those clothes.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Colliers come by the door every day mistress,
Nay, this is market-day too, poulterers, butchers,
They would have lain most daintily in a pannier,
And kept veal from the wind.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Those clothes much trouble me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'faith, and he were a gentleman as he seemed to be,
They would trouble him too I think;
Methinks he should have small desire to keep 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'faith and less pride to wear 'em, I should think wench,
Unless he keep 'em as a testimony
For after-times to show what misery
He passed in his young days, and then weep over 'em.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Weep mistress? nay sure methinks he should not weep for laughing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Martino? o we're spoiled wench, are they come then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Mistress, be of good cheer, I have excellent news for you, comfort your heart, what have you to breakfast mistress, you shall have all again, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What says he wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I'm loath to understand him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Give me a note of all your things sweet mistress,
you shall not lose a hair, take't of my word
We have him safe enough.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Olas, sweet wench
This man talks fearfully.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And I know not what yet
That's the worst mistress.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Can you tell me pray,
Whether the rascal has broke ope my desk or no,
There's a fine little barrel of pom-citrons
Would have served me this seven year, o, and my fig-cheese.
The fig of everlasting obloquy
Go with him if he have eat it, I'll make haste
He cannot eat it all yet, he was taken mistress
Grossly, and beastly, how do you think i'faith?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I know not sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Troth in my master's clothes,
Would any thief but a beast been taken so?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wench, wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I have grief enough of mine own to tend mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Did he confess the robbery?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O no, no mistress
He's a young cunning rascal, he confessed nothing;
While we were examining on him, he took away
My master's purse and mine, but confessed nothing still.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That's but some slanderous injury raised against him.
Came not your Mr. with you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No sweet mistress.
I must make haste and meet him pray dispatch me then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I have looked over all with special heedfulness,
There's nothing missed, I can assure you sir
But that suit of your masters.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'm right glad on't that suit would hang him yet I would not have him hanged in that suit though, it will disgrace my master's fashion for ever, and make it as hateful as yellow bands.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O what shall's do wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Tis no marvel mistress
The poor young gentleman could not keep his promise.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Alas sweet man, has confessed nothing ye wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: That shows his constancy, and love to you mistress:
but you must do't of force, there is no help for't,
The truth can neither shame nor hurt you much,
Let 'em make what they can on't, 'twere sin and pity i'faith
To cast away so sweet a gentleman,
For such a pair of infidel hose and doublet,
I would not hang a Jew for a whole wardrobe on 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou sayest true wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O, o, they're come again mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Signior Ansaldo?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: The same mightily crossed lady,
But past hope freed again by a doctor's means,
A man of art, I know not justly what indeed,
But pity, and the fortunate gold you gave me,
Wrought my release between 'em.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Met you not
My husband's man?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I took such strange ways lady
I hardly met a creature.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O most welcome

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But how shall we bestow him now we have him mrs.?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Alas, that's true.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Martino may come back again.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Step you into that little chamber speedily sir,
And dress him up in one of my gowns and head-tires
His youth will well endure it.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: That will be admirable.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay do't, do't quickly then, and cut that suit
Into a hundred pieces, that it may never be known again.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: A hundreth? nay ten thousand at the least mris.
For if there be a piece of that suit left, as big as my nail,
The deed will come out, 'tis worse than a murder,
I fear 'twill never be hid.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Away, do your endeavour, and dispatch wench,
I've thought upon a way of certain safety,
And I may keep him while I have him too,
Without suspicion now: I've heard o'th' like:
A gentleman, that for a lady's love
Was thought six months her woman, tended on her
In her own garments, and she being a widow,
Lay night by night with her in way of comfort,
marry in conclusion match they did together,
Would I'd a copy of the same conclusion:
He's come himself now, if thou beest a happy wench
Be fortunate in thy speed, I'll delay time
With all the means I can: o welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I'll speak to you anon wife, and kiss you shortly,
I'm very busy yet: cocksey-down, Mem-berrie,
Her manner house at Well-dun.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's that good sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The widows your sweet sister's deed of gift;
Sh'as made all her estate over to me wench:
She'll be too hard for 'em all: and now come buss me
Good luck after thieves handsel.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O 'tis happy sir
You have him fast.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I ha' laid him safe enough wench.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I was so lost in joy at the report on't
I quite forgotten one thing to tell Martino.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What's that sweet blood?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He, and his villain's sir
Robbed a sweet gentlewoman last night.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, most uncivilly and basely stripped her sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O barbarous slaves.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I was e'en fain for woman-hood's sake
(Alas) and charities, to receive her in,
And clothe her poor wants in a suit of mine.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: 'Twas most religiously done: I long for her;
Who have I brought to see thee think'st thou woman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay sir, I know not.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Guess, I prithee heartily:
An enemy of thine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That I hope you have not sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: But all was done in jest: he cries thee mercy,
Francisco sirrah.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O; I think not on him.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That letter was but written to try thy constancy,
He confessed all to me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Joy on him sir,[enter Francisco.]
So far am I from malice, look you sir;
welcome sweet signior; but I'll never trust you sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Faith I'm beholding to thee wife, for this.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Methinks, I enter now this house with joy,
Sweet peace, and quietness of conscience,
I wear no guilty blush upon my cheek
For a sin stamped last midnight: I can talk now
With that kind man, and not abuse him inwardly,
With any scornful thought made of his shame:
What a sweet being is an honest mind?
It speaks peace to itself, and all mankind.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Master.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: There's another robbery done sirrah,
By the same party.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What? your worship mocks,
Under correction.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I forgotten to tell thee
He robbed a lovely gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O pagan,
This fellow will be stoned to death with pipkins,
Your women in the suburbs will so maul him
With broken crew●es, and pitchers without ears,
He will never die alive, that's my opinion.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Look you your judgement's gentlemen, yours especially
Signior Francisco, whose mere object now
Is woman at these years, that's the eye saint I know
Amongst young gallants, husband, you have a glimpse too;
You offer half an eye, as old as you are,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: By'r lady better wench: an eye, and a half I troa,
I should be sorry else.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What think you now sirs
Is't not a goodly manly gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Beshrew my heart else wife.
Pray soft a little signior you're but my guest remember,
I'm Mr. of the house, I'll have the first buss.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But husband, 'tis the courtesy of all places
To give a stranger ever the first bit.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: In woodcock or so, but there's no heed to be taken in mutton;
we commonly fall so roundly to that we forget ourselves:
I'm sorry for thy fortune, but thou'rt welcome lady

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My master kisses, as I've heard a hackney man cheer up his mare, chap, chap.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I have him fast lady, and he shall lie by't close,

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You cannot do me a greater pleasure sir,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I'm happily glad on't.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Methinks there's somewhat whispers in my soul,
This is the hour, I must begin my acquaintance
With honest love, and banish all loose thoughts;
My fate speaks to me from the modest eye
Of yond sweet gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wench, wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Pish, hold in your breath mistress,
If you be seen to laugh, you spoil all presently,
I keep it in with all the might I have — puh.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Pray what young gentleman's that sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: An honest boy i'faith,
And came of a good kind: dost like him lady,
I would thou hadst him, and thou beest not promised,
He's worth ten thousand dollars.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: By this light mistress, my master will go near to make a match anon, methinks I dream of admirable sport mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Peace, thou art a drab.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Come hither now Francisco,
I've know the time, I've had a better stomach;
Now I can dine with looking upon meat.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That face deserved a better fortune lady
Than last night's rudeness showed.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: We cannot be
Our choosers sir in our own destiny.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I return better pleased, than when I went.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And could that beastly imp rob you forsooth?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Most true forsooth,
I will not altogether sir, disgrace you,
Because you look half like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And that's the mother's half.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: There's my hand for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I swear you could not give me any thing
I love better, a hand gets me my living;
o sweet lemon-peel.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: May I request a modest word or two lady
In private with you?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To make it sure from all suspect of injury,
Or unbeseeming private, which heaven knows
Is not my aim now, I'll entreat this gentleman
For an ear witness unto all our conference.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Why so, I am content sir,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: So am I lady ..

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O master, here's a rare bedfellow for my mistress tonight ,
For you know we must both out of town again.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That's true Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do but think how they'll lie telling of tales together
The pretiest.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The prettiliest indeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Their tongues will never lyn wagging master.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Never Martino, never.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Take heed you be not heard.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I fear you most mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Me fool? ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Why look you mistress: faith you're faulty, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well said i'faith, where lies the fault now gossip.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O for a husband; I shall burst with laughing else,
This house is able to spoil any maid.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'll be revenged now soundly of Francisco
For failing me when time was.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Are you there mistress? I thought you would not forget that
However , a good turn disappointed is ever the last thing
That a woman forgives, she'll scarce do't when she's speechless,
Nay, though she hold up her whole hand for all other injuries,
She'll forgive that but with one finger.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'll vex his heart as much as he mocked mine.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: But that may mar your hopes too, if our gentlewoman be known to be a man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not as I'll work it;
I would not lose this sweet revenge methinks
For a whole fortnight of the old man's absence,
Which is the sweetest benefit next to this:
Why how now sir, what course take you for laughing?
We are undone for one.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Faith with great pain,
Stifle it, and keep it in: I ha' no recipe for't.
But pray, in sadness say; what is the gentleman,
I never knew his like for tedious urgings,
He will receive no answer.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Would he would not sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Says I'm ordained for him: merely for him,
And that his wiving fate speaks in me to him;
Will force on me a jointure speedily
Of some seven thousand dollars.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Would thou hadst 'em sir: I know he can and he will.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: For wonders pity; what is this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'faith shall I tell you sir,
One that would make an excellent honest husband
For her that's a just maid at one and twenty;
For on my conscience he has his maidenhead yet.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Fie, out upon him beast.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, if you love me.
Give way but to one thing I shall request of you.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Your courtesies you know may lay commands on me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then at his next solicitings, let a consent
Seem to come from you; 'twill make noble sport sir,
We'll get jointure and all; but you must bear
Yourself most affable to all his purposes.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I can do that.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ay, and take head of laughing.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I've bide the worst of that already lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Peace, set your countenance then; for here he comes.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: There is no middle continent in this passion,
I feel it since, it must be love, or death
It was ordained for one.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Signior Francisco,
I'm sorry 'twas your fortune, in my house sir,
To have so violent a stroke come to you:
The gentlewoman's a stranger pray be counselled sir,
Till you hear further of her friends and portion.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis only but her love that I desire,
She comes most rich in that.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But be advised though,
I think she's rich heir, but see the proof sir,
Before you make her such a generous jointure.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis mine, and I will do't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She shall be yours too,
If I may rule her then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You speak all sweetness.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She likes your person well, I tell you so much,
But take no note I said so.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come lady, come, the gentleman desertful,
And oh my conscience honest.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Blame me not, I am a maid, and fearful.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Never truth came perfecter from man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Give her a lip-taste,
That she herself may praise it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Yea, a match i'faith: my house is luckily for 'em
Now Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Master, the widow has the day.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The day?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She's overthrown my youngster.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Precious tidings,
Clap down four woodcocks more.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They're all at hand sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What both her adversaries too.

div.stage: Enter Valeria, Ricardo, and two suitors.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They're come sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: God bid the cook serve in two geese in a dish.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I like your conceit master beyond utterance.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Welcome sweet sister; which is the man must have you.
I'd welcome nobody else.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Come to me then sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Are ye he 'Faith, my chain of gold? I'm glad on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I wonder you can have the face to follow me,
That have so prosecuted things against me,
But I ha' resolved myself 'tis done to spite me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: O dearth of truth.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Nay, do not spoil thy hair,
Hold, hold I say, I'll get thee a widow somewhere.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: If hand and faith be nothing for a contract,
What shall man hope?

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: 'Twas wont to be enough, honey.
When there was honest meaning amongst widows,
But since your bribes came in, 'tis not allowed
A contract without gifts to bind it fast,
Every thing now must have a feeling first:
Do I come near you widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No indeed sir,
Nor ever shall I hope: and for your comfort sir,
That sought all means t'entrap me for my wealth,
Had law unfortunately put you upon me,
You had lost your labour, all your aim, and hopes sir:
Here stands the honest gentleman my brother
To whom I've made a deed of gift of all.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I that sheh 'As i'faith, I thank her gentlemen
Look you here sirs.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I must not look for pleasures
That give more grief if they prove false, or fail us
Then ever they gave joy.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Ha'you served me so widow

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: I'm glad thou hast her not, laugh at him honey; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I must take one that loves me for myself:
Here's as old gentleman looks not after wealth
But virtue, manners, and conditions.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Yes by my faith: I must have lordships too widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Your manners, virtue, and conditions widow.
Are pretty things within doors, I like well on 'em,
But I must have somewhat with outlying or being
In the tenure or occupation of me such a one: ha?
Those are fine things indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why sir, you swore to me it was for love.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: True; but there's two words to a bargain ever
All the world over, and if love be one
I'm sure money's the other; 'tis no bargain else:
Pardon me, I must dine, as well as sup widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Cry mercy, I mistook you all this while sir.
It was this ancient gentleman indeed,
Whom I crave pardon on.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: What of me widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Alas I have wronged you sir; 'twas you that swore
you loved me for myself?

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: By my troth but I did not.
Come, father not your lies upon me widow:
I love you for yourself? spit at me gentlemen
If ever I'd such a thought, fetch me in widow:
You'll find your reach too short.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why you have enough you say.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.p: Ay, but I will have my humour too; you never think of that, they're coach horses, they go together still.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Whom should a widow trust: I'll swear 'twas one of you
That made me believe so: mass, think 'twas you sir
Now I remember me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I swore too much
To be believed so little.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Was it you then?
Beshrew my heart for wronging of you.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Welcome blessing,
Are you nine faithfully now?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As love can make one.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Why this fills the commonwealth so full of beggars,
Marrying for love, which none of mine shall do.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But now I think on't: we must part again sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Again?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You're in debt, and I, in doubt of all,
Left myself nothing too; we must not hold,
Want on both sides makes all affection cold:
I shall not keep you from that gentleman,
You'll be his more than mine and when he list
He'll make you lie from me in some sour prison,
Then let him take you now for altogether sir,
For he that's mine shall be all mine or nothing.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I never felt the evil of my debts
Till this afflicting minute.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.p: I'll be mad once in my days: I have enough to cure me, and I will have my humour, they're now but desperate debts again, I never look for 'em,
sp.l: And ever since I knew what malice was
I always held it sweeter to sow mischief.
Than to receive money; 'tis the finer pleasure.
I'll give him in his bonds as 'twere in pity
To make the match, and bring 'em both to beggary,
Then will they never agree; that's a sure point,
He'll give her a black eye within these three days,
Beat half her teeth out by Alhall join,
And break the little householdstuff they have
With throwing at one another: oh sweet sport.
Come widow, come, I'll try your honesty
Here to my honey you've made many proffers,
I fear they're all but tricks: here are his debts gentlemen:
How I came by 'em I know best myself.
Take him before us faithfully for your husband
And he shall tear 'em all before your face widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Else may all faith refuse me:

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: Tear 'em honey
'Tis firm in law, a consideration given:
What with thy teeth? thoul't shortly tear her so
That's all my hope, thou'dst never had 'em else
I've enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I'm now at liberty widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'll be so too
And then I come to thee: give me this from you brother,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Hold sister: sister.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Look you, the deed of gift sir, I'm as free
He that has me, has all, and thou art he.
1. 2. How's that?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You're bobbed, 'twas but a deed in trust
And all to prove thee, whom I have found most just.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I'm bobbed among the rest too: I'd have sworn
T'had been a thing for me, and my heirs for ever;
If I'd but got it up to the black box above
I had been passed redemption

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: How am I cheated?

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: I hope you'll have the conscience now to pay me sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: O wicked man, sour of strife and envy, open not thy lips.

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: How, how's this?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thou hast no charge at all, no child of thine own
But two thou gottest once of a scowring woman,
And they are both well provided for, they're i'th hospital,
Thou hast ten thousand pound to bury thee,
hang thyself when thou wilt, a slave go with thee

sp.speaker: 2 suitor.
sp.l: I'm gone, my goodness comes all out together.
I have enough, but I have not my humour.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O master, gentlemen: and you sweet widow
I think you are no forwarder yet, I know not,
If ever you be sure to laugh again,
Now is the time.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why what's the matter wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Speak, speak.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Ha, a marriage, a marriage, I cannot tel't for laughing: ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A marriage do you make that a laughing matter?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Ha: ay, and you'll make it so when you know all,
Here they come, here they come, one man married to another.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How? man to man?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I man to man i'faith
There'll be good sport at night to bring 'em both to bed;
Do you see 'em now, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: My daughter Martia.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O my father: your love, and pardon sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis she indeed gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I have been disobedient I confess
Unto your mind, and heaven has punished me
With much affliction since I fled your sight;
But finding reconcilement from above
In peace of heart; the next I hopes your love.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: I cannot but forgive thee now I see thee,
Thou fledst a happy fortune of an old man,
But Francisco's of a noble family.
Though he be somewhat spent.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I loved her not sir
As she was yours, for I protest I knew't not,
But for herself sir, and her own deserving,
Which had you been as foul, as you've been spiteful
I should have loved in her.

sp.speaker: 1 suitor.
sp.l: Well, hold your prating sir,
You're not like to lose by't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O Violetta, who shall laugh at us now?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: The child unborn mistress.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Be good.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Be honest.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Heaven will not let you sin, and you'd be careful.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What means it sends to help you, think and mend,
You're as much bound as we, to praise that friend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am so, and I will so.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Marry you speedily,
Children tame you, you'll die like a wild beast else.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I by my troth should I, I've much ado to forbear
Laughing now, more's my hard fortune.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O master, mistress, and you gentles all;
To horse, to horse presently, if you mean to do your country any service.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Art not ashamed Martino, to talk of divorcing so openly
Before young married couples thus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It does concern the commonwealth and me,
And you master, and all: the thieves are taken.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What sayest Martino,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: La, here's common-wealths-men,
The man of art master, that cupped your eyes
Is proved an arrant rascal: and his man
That drew my tooth, an excellent purse-drawer,
I felt no pain in that, it went insensibly:
Such notable villainies confessed.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Stop there sir:
We'll have time for them: come gentlefolks,
Take a slight meal with us: but the best cheer
Is perfect joy, and that we wish all here. —

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: A sport, only for Christmas, is the play
This hour presents to you; to make you merry,
Is all th' ambition 'thas; and fullest aim
Bent at your smiles, to win itself a name:
And if you edge be not quite taken off,
Wearied with sports, I hope 'twill make you laugh.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Stay, stay, sir, I'm as hungry of my widow
As you can be upon your maid believe it,
But we must come to our desires in order,
There's duties to be paid, ere we go further;
He that without your likings, leaves this place,
Is like one falls to meat, and forgets grace.
And that's not handsome trust me, no,
Our rights being paid, and your loves understood,
My widow, and my meat, than does me good;
I ha' no money wench, I told thee true,
For my report, pray let her hear't from you,

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
